body:
Its works great for me on an Ubuntu 16.04 host. Follow NVIDIA's [installation guide](https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/sdk/cudnn-install/index.html). After that, install the `pip` dependencies and you are really to execute from script.

But the easiest way to build a solid DFL environment is inside a Docker container. You will not have to do any manual confiruation steps on the host machine, besides installing `nvidia-docker`. If you are comfortable using Docker environments, try this Dockerfile:

https://gist.github.com/TooMuchFun/5f9cc9807e9d302f6b332a3d296169d9

Please see the comment below the code for an example on how to run it. Let me know if it works for you. If there is enough interest it could probably be merged into the main fork.
@TooMuchFun newbie here, could you please list down the steps on how to run DeepFaceLab on Ubuntu please? I don't have Windows on my machine but would really love to use DFL. thank you!
@yg2dras1 try the `apt-get` and `pip` steps from each `RUN` command used in [this Dockerfile](https://gist.github.com/TooMuchFun/5f9cc9807e9d302f6b332a3d296169d9).

https://github.com/lbfs/DeepFaceLab_Linux I've forked the codebase and converted some of the scripts to run on Ubuntu 18.04 LTS. Unsure how actively I will maintain this though and if it works on AWS since I'm not familiar enough with it.

I have very little ability to test Mac OS in my environment. You can use homebrew to install the same dependencies that the apt install command requests. The rest of the instructions are the same except instead of using requirements-cuda9-cudnn7.txt you want to use requirements-cpu.txt

I'm not sure if using Mac OS for training is the best idea considering OpenCL and OpenGL support was dropped in Mac OS Mojave and you're locked to CPU based training as a result of tensorflow-gpu not being well supported.
@lbfs  we need main.sh file for unix version

Look in my scripts directory in my repo, there is no reason to have a main.sh.

Please direct any further questions to my repo so I can better keep track of things.

> Please direct any further questions to my repo to avoid spamming this one for no reason.

Then it would probably be a good idea to enable the issue section for your fork.

> > Please direct any further questions to my repo to avoid spamming this one for no reason.
> 
> Then it would probably be a good idea to enable the issue section for your fork.

Sure， we need issue section
@HelpSeeker @oracle9i88 I've enabled the issues section, I'm not sure how it got disabled, but I've reenabled it again.
@lbfs ffmpeg and ffprobe must be in env access
